newsitem.title: USA: MCI long distance revenues up 11.4 pct.
newsitem.headline: MCI long distance revenues up 11.4 pct.

text.p: MCI Communications Corp said on Tuesday its third quarter long distance revenues rose 11.4 percent to $4.3 billion from a year ago, exceeding its traffic growth of 11.0 percent over the same period.
"The gap (revenue growth minus traffic growth) grew a positive 0.4 percent from a year ago," chief financial officer Doug Maine told an analysts' conference call.

This improvement, which means each minute spent on the network earns the company more money, came partly from a fall in access charges by regional Bells and lower settlement rates paid on outbound international calls.

Less low-revenue carriage of traffic for other telecommunications firms, compared with a year ago, improved the ratio, but there was some offset from increased provisions for uncollectible revenues, Maine said.

MCI said wireless revenues fell by $13 million to $83 million from a year ago, because of a decline in paging customers while the company reorganized its marketing approach to cut customer turnover, or churn.
"Look for declines in paging customer accounts to continue during the fourth quarter, with a pickup in net customers during 1997," Maine said.
MCI paging customers fell to 342,000 from 474,000 in the second quarter. No year-ago figure was given.
However, cellular telephone customers rose to 407,000, 28 percent up from a year ago. MCI resells both paging and cellular services carried on the networks of others.
Maine said business services continued to grow very strongly, with double digit revenue gains continuing.
Data services grew revenues 24 percent from a year ago, dedicated access rose 30 percent and frame relay and hyperstream high speed data services doubled.
Pre-paid phone card revenues trebled from a year ago.
Internet access revenues rose 80 percent from the second quarter. The company had not begun the service a year ago.
Maine said that service guarantees and customizing data services had allowed MCI to get an even stronger grip on the business market.
"This has enabled MCI to command a premium in the (business) marketplace over all other carriers while at the same time increasing market share," he said.
He told analysts to look for MCI's proportion of total revenues derived from business markets to continue to increase from the current two-thirds.
In the consumer long distance market, which is beset by fierce competition from resellers and intense promotional activity by AT&T Corp, Maine said MCI had changed its sales and marketing focus.
"We're focused on long term profitability, not the maximum number of customer additions," he said.

It has begun to focus on high value-added customers and decreasing the value of promotional schemes by 70 percent from a year ago. Though customer churn is up year on year, it has already fallen from the second quarter, he said. -- Nick Louth, New York Newsroom 212 859 1712
